title: Nimue rewrite: Booster Pathway
text: Compartment definitions follows: \(uV\) Un-vaccinated population, \(pV_i\) Partially vaccinated/protected population (.e. first dose two dose regimen), \(fV_i\) Fully vaccinated/protected population (.e. doses two dose regimen). \(bV_i\) Boosted population (least one booster dose). Full dose boosted compartments feed waned compartments represent reduced vaccine efficacy time. Transition rates defined : \(fD_t\) Daily time-series first doses, \(sD_t\) inferred delay doses (~60 days), \(bD_{1,t}\) Daily time-series initial booster doses, \(bD_{2,t}\) Daily time-series follow-booster doses, can limited certain age groups, \(w_p\) Rate waning initial dose protection, \(w_i\) Rate waning boosted dose protection. Eligibility follow-boosters can restricted certain age groups parameter vaccine_booster_follow_up_coverage.

title: Nimue rewrite: Booster Pathway
text: user expected provide time-series primary doses, booster doses. model primarily usage global_lmic_reports, intended normal usage. objects necessary MCMC fitting can access : model can run squire nimue non-exported function squire.page:::run_booster.  delay development vaccination protection nimue removed, time-series first/second doses provided model internally adjusted via Erlang distribution shape 2 rate 1/7 simulate effect. parameters customizable model. simulate primary single dose vaccine (.e. Janssen) set first second dose efficacies desired level set second dose delay 1.
code: #model object squire.page::nimue_booster_model() #likelihood function squire.page::calc_loglikelihood_booster() #pmcmc object squire.page::pmcmc_drjacoby(log_likelihood = squire.page::calc_loglikelihood_booster,                             nimue_booster_model = squire.page::nimue_booster_model,                             ... #specific arguments here                             ) #alternatively rt_optimise(squire_model = squire.page::nimue_booster_model(),             ... #Parameter arguments here             ) squire.page:::run_booster(   country = "United Kingdom",   primary_doses = c(100, 1000, 500, 0),   tt_primary_doses = c(0, 10, 50, 150),   second_dose_delay = 60,   booster_doses = c(0, 500, 750),   tt_booster_doses = c(0, 200, 400),   time_period  = 365*2,   vaccine_booster_follow_up_coverage = c(rep(0, 17 - 5), rep(1, 5)) ) %>%    squire.page::nimue_format(var_select = c("vaccinated_first_dose", "vaccinated_second_dose", "vaccinated_second_waned",                                            "vaccinated_booster_dose", "vaccinated_booster_waned")) %>%    tibble() %>%    pivot_wider(names_from = compartment, values_from = y) %>%    transmute(     t = t,     `Partial` = vaccinated_first_dose - vaccinated_second_dose,     `Primary` = vaccinated_second_dose - vaccinated_booster_dose - vaccinated_second_waned,     `Waned (Primary)` = vaccinated_second_waned,     `Boosted` = vaccinated_booster_dose - vaccinated_booster_waned,     `Waned (Boosted)` = vaccinated_booster_waned   ) %>%   pivot_longer(c(`Partial`, `Primary`,     `Waned (Primary)`,     `Boosted`,     `Waned (Boosted)`),                names_to = "Vaccine Protection", values_to = "Population") %>%    ggplot(aes(x = t, y = `Population`, colour = `Vaccine Protection`)) +    geom_line()

title: Nimue rewrite: Booster Pathway
text: Default parameter values chosen representative vaccination programmes LMIC LIC countries wild-type variant represent single vaccine chosen range values represent roughly Adenovirus, Whole Virus, Subunit vaccines. Note work involving efficacies Delta Omicron calculated elsewhere. Vaccine Efficacies: Waning Rates: \(w_p\) = 0.007466205 (134 days) \(w_1\) = 0.00807429 (123.8 days) \(w_2\) = 0.03331390 (30 days) Delay second dose protection assumed 60 days. calculate values utilised approach taken previously waning vaccine efficacy via AB titres (Report 48). took assumed non-waned efficacies created median waning curve values. fit waning rates waned compartment values recreate curves. plots fits shown .

title: Nimue rewrite: Booster Pathway
text: Comparing two models absence vaccinations give identical results, outside minor variations due random ages initial infections.  Comparing two models primary doses (flat efficacy first/second) waning also identical  waning expect see minor difference booster single compartment represent primary dose waning, though overall rates similar.  plot increase duration waning nimue 14 days account fact booster model 14 day delay developing VE applied first second doses. Otherwise second peak occurs couple days sooner nimue. simulate two doses first consider situation delay 60 days two, nimue translated dose ratio VE scaled. nimue must increase duration protection account delay doses.  Lastly including boosters booster model, expect delay deaths waning overwhelms.

title: New Fitting Method: Rt Optimisation
text: Inputs assumed set distributions non \(R_t\) parameters set deaths occur set time periods, \(D_i\) deaths occur time period \([t_{f,}, t_{s,}]\) \(\1\) \(T_D\). assume epidemic begins time 0. define parameters vary fitting process \(\boldsymbol{R} = \{R_t;\ t\0\mathrm{\ \ }T_R\}\). \(R_t\) comes effect time \(t_{R_t}\), default every 14 days \(T_R = T_D - \max{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\). Generate \(N\) samples assumed distributions non \(R_t\) parameters. discussed section Parameter Uncertainty. \(R_0\) set bounds \([0, t_{R_{1}} + \max(\boldsymbol{\lambda})]\), \(R_{T_R}\) set bounds \({t_{R_{T_R}} + \min(\boldsymbol{\lambda}), t_{s,T_D}}\). simplity define \(\boldsymbol{i_{R_t}} = \{;\ t_{s,} \geq t_{R_t} + \min(\boldsymbol{\lambda})\ \&\ t_{f,} \leq \max(\boldsymbol{\lambda})\}\), indexes deaths occur within \(R_t\)’s fitting period Begin estimation procedure estimating \(R_0\) \(I_0\), initial number infections. \(I_0\) uniformly spread across unvaccinated working age population. optimising \(R_t\) set upper lower bounds values can take, hyper parameters \(\alpha, \beta\) \(\alpha > \beta\) \(\alpha = 10, \beta = 0.5\) default. optimise \(I_0\) split given range numbers \(N_p\) values, ’ll call \(P_{I_0}\). find optimal values \(R_0\) \(I_0\) optimise log-likelihoods element \(P_{I_0}\) terms \(R_t\) using Brent optmisation method. likelihood uses negative binomial distribution mean equal modelled deaths \(k\) user defined dispersion parameter \(D_i\), deaths fall within \(R_0\) fitting window per step 2. take \(I_0\) \(R_t\) highest optimised likelihood values \(R_0\) \(I_0\). Using \(R_0\) \(I_0\) calculate state models compartments time \(t_{R_1}\), call \(\boldsymbol{I_{R_1}}\). Choose \(R_t\) optimising log-likelihood \(D_i\) \(\i_{R_t}\) \(R_t\) \(\boldsymbol{I_{R_t}}\) calculate \(\boldsymbol{I_{R_{t+1}}}\) occurs time \(t_{R_t + 1}\). end set \(\boldsymbol{R}\) sample modelled deaths similar observed deaths.

title: New Fitting Method: Rt Optimisation
text: Let \(\boldsymbol{p}\) set non-\(R_t\) model parameters. let \(m_{}(\boldsymbol{p}, \boldsymbol{I_{R_{t}}}, R_t, t)\) function returns model state time \(t\), given state model \(R_{t+1}\) comes effect, \(m_{d}(\boldsymbol{p}, \boldsymbol{I_{R_t}}, R_t, t_s, t_f)\) function produces number deaths model occuring time period \([t_s, t_f]\). \(\boldsymbol{p}\): \[ \{R_0, I_0\} = \mathrm{argmax}_{x,y \[\alpha, \beta] \times \boldsymbol{P_{I_0}}}\left(   \prod_{\\boldsymbol{i_{R_0}}}\frac{\Gamma(D_i + n_i)}{\Gamma(n_i)D_i!}(1-p_i)^{D_i}p_i^{n_i} \right), \] : \[ p_i = \frac{k}{k + \mu_i},\ n_i = \frac{p_i \times \mu_i}{1-p_i} ,\ \ \mu_i =  m_d(\boldsymbol{p}, y, x, t_{s,}, t_{f,}). \] \(\boldsymbol{I_{R_1}} = m_I(\boldsymbol{p}, I_0, R_0, t_{R_1})\), note treat \(I_0\) \(\boldsymbol{I_{R_0}}\) interchangeably . \[  R_t = \mathrm{argmax}_{x \\boldsymbol{P_{R_t}}}\left(  \prod_{\\boldsymbol{i_{R_t}}}\frac{\Gamma(D_i + n_i)}{\Gamma(n_i)D_i!}(1-p_i)^{D_i}p_i^{n_i} \right)  \] : \[  p_i = \frac{k}{k + \mu_i},\ \ n_i = \frac{p_i \times \mu_i}{1-p_i},\ \ \mu_i =  m_d(\boldsymbol{p}, \boldsymbol{I_{R_t}}, x, t_{s,}, t_{f,}).  \] \(\boldsymbol{I_{R_{t+1}}} = m_I(\boldsymbol{p}, \boldsymbol{I_{R_{t}}}, R_t, t_{R_{t+1}})\)

title: New Fitting Method: Rt Optimisation
text: necessary bound \(R_t\) certain thresholds avoid dramatically high low changes. far fits seem work well \(R_t\) ranges around \(0.5\) \(0.9\) \(10\), though possible curve matched algorithm simple bounds.

what: Functions used in global-lmic-reports-orderly and other repos
title: Functions used in global-lmic-reports-orderly and other repos
text: package stores miscellaneous R functions used repo global-lmic-reports repos use nimue fits. thinking behind storing external package means can kept consistent across multiple repos orderly tasks. majority functions variations fitting functions squire. added base squire nimue packages specific usage. Named position typically held becoming squire.

title: Functions used in global-lmic-reports-orderly and other repos
text: Please see GitHub page information. Likelihood MCMC functions excess mortality fitting. account fitting weekly data daily, also allow poisson instead negative binomial fitting. Likelihood functions LMIC-reports. allow fitting cases tail epidemic time varying hospitalisation modifiers (added squire point). Functions simulate draws model output given different numbers vaccines. Also similar function LMICs (simplify ). Functions setting future scenarios LMIC projections. different method fitting squire/nimue model adjusting Rt values short periods time. Various functions plotting R deaths time, compatible version fits.

title: A function to load and summarise the deaths averted data — loadCounterfactualData
code: loadCounterfactualData(   counterfactuals,   group_by,   quantileSamples = 2000,   exclude_iso3cs = NULL )

title: A function to load and summarise the deaths averted data — loadCounterfactualData
text: counterfactuals counterfactuals load. vector strings. Since large files, recommended load one counterfactual time. group_by vector strings variables group summary , e.g. Iso3c code, age_group date. quantileSamples used dataset grouped country. number combinations randomly draw. Defaults 2000. NULL creates wider interval based ordering samples. exclude_iso3cs vector iso3cs exclude summaries, default = NULL.

text: squire object provided feed squire::format_output. However, please note variables can selected squire.

title: Nimue format that returns just compartments/summaries requested — nimue_format
code: nimue_format(   out,   var_select = NULL,   reduce_age = TRUE,   combine_compartments = TRUE,   date_0 = NULL,   mean_over_80_age = 82.5,   case_to_infection_ratio = 0.195 )

title: Nimue format that returns just compartments/summaries requested — nimue_format
text: nimue_simulation squire_simulation object var_select Vector compartment names, e.g. c("S", "R"). addition number summary compartment can requested. include: "deaths" Daily Deaths "infections" Daily Infections "hospital_occupancy" See description "ICU_occupancy" See description "hospital_demand" See description "ICU_demand" See description "hospital_incidence" See description "ICU_incidence" See description "hospitalisations" See description "vaccines", "unvaccinated", "vaccinated", "priorvaccinated" Vaccine outputs "long_covid" Long COVID estimates reduce_age Collapse age-dimension, calculating total compartment. combine_compartments Collapse compartments type together (e.g. E1 E2 -> E) date_0 Date time 0, specified date column added mean_over_80_age Mean age 80 population calculating long covid incidence. Default = 82.5 case_to_infection_ratio Ratio infections cases long covid calculation. Default = 0.195 UK ONS analyses

title: Nimue format that returns just compartments/summaries requested — nimue_format
text: Formatted long data.frame

title: Nimue format that returns just compartments/summaries requested — nimue_format
text: better define summaries related healthcare pathway: demand total number requiring hospitalisation ICU care given time, regardless received occupancy total number received ICU hospital care given time incidence total number new people require hospital ICU care hospitalisations Sum new people recieving hospital ICU care Note: confusing seemingly inconsistent .e. hospital_incidence capture recovering ICU hospitalisations stated equal sum incidences elsewhere.

title: Nimue format that returns just compartments/summaries requested — nimue_format
code: #generate some outputs for the afghanistan fit and pass through to format #getting deaths and long covid estimates if (FALSE) { generate_draws(afg_fit) %>%   nimue_format(var_select = c("deaths", "long_covid")) }

text: x excess_nimue_simulation object var_select Vector variable names plot (default ) replicates Plot replicates summarise Logical, add summary line ci logical add confidence interval ribbon q Quantiles upper lower interval ribbon summary_f Function summarise compartment passed fun argument stat_summary x_var X variable use plotting (default "t", can set , "date", date_0 provided), cause date plotted rather time. date_0 Date time 0 (e.g. "2020-03-01"), specified date column added particle_fit squire_simulation provided result running particle filter, want just plot fit. Default = FALSE ... additional arguments affecting plot produced.

what:
Provide projections from calibrated simulations by changing RO, contact
matrices or bed availability. — projections
title:
Provide projections from calibrated simulations by changing RO, contact
matrices or bed availability. — projections
text: extends previous projections can pass lists argument get passed simulation replicate.

title:
Provide projections from calibrated simulations by changing RO, contact
matrices or bed availability. — projections
code: projections(r, ...)  # S3 method for default projections(r, ...)  # S3 method for rt_optimised projections(   r,   time_period,   R0 = NULL,   R0_change = NULL,   tt_R0 = NULL,   contact_matrix_set = NULL,   contact_matrix_set_change = NULL,   tt_contact_matrix = NULL,   hosp_bed_capacity = NULL,   hosp_bed_capacity_change = NULL,   tt_hosp_beds = NULL,   ICU_bed_capacity = NULL,   ICU_bed_capacity_change = NULL,   tt_ICU_beds = NULL,   to_be_run = TRUE,   model_user_args = NULL,   ... )

title:
Provide projections from calibrated simulations by changing RO, contact
matrices or bed availability. — projections
text: r Calibrated {squire_simulation} {rt_optimised} object. ... parameters, used pass parameters methods time_period many days projection. Default = NULL, carry projection forward t = 0 calibration (.e. number days set calibrate using forecast) R0 Numeric vector R0 t = 0 calibration. E.g. R0 = c(2, 1). Default = NULL, use R0_change alter R0 provided. R0_change Numeric vector relative changes R0 relative final R0 used calibration (.e. t = 0 calibration) E.g. R0 = c(0.8, 0.5). Default = NULL, use R0 parameterise changes R0 provided. tt_R0 Change time points R0 contact_matrix_set Contact matrices used simulation. Default = NULL, use contact_matrix_set_change alter contact matrix provided. contact_matrix_set_change Numeric vector relative changes contact matrix realtive final contact matrix used calibration (.e. t = 0 calibration). E.g. contact_matrix_set_change = c(0.8, 0.5). Default = NULL, use contact_matrix_set parameterise changes contact matrices provided. tt_contact_matrix Time change points matrix change. Default = 0 hosp_bed_capacity Numeric vector hospital bed capacity t = 0 calibration. Default = NULL, use hosp_bed_capacity_change alter hosp_bed_capacity provided. hosp_bed_capacity_change Numeric vector relative changes hospital bed capacity relative final hospital bed capacity used calibration (.e. t = 0 calibration). E.g. hosp_bed_capacity_change = c(0.8, 0.5). Default = NULL, use hosp_bed_capacity parameterise changes hospital bed capacity provided. tt_hosp_beds Change time points hosp_bed_capacity ICU_bed_capacity Numeric vector ICU bed capacity t = 0 calibration. Default = NULL, use ICU_bed_capacity_change alter ICU_bed_capacity provided. ICU_bed_capacity_change Numeric vector relative changes ICU bed capacity relative final ICU bed capacity used calibration (.e. t = 0 calibration). E.g. ICU_bed_capacity_change = c(0.8, 0.5). Default = NULL, use ICU_bed_capacity parameterise changes ICU bed capacity provided. tt_ICU_beds Change time points ICU_bed_capacity to_be_run List logicals whether replicate run. Default = TRUE, causes replictes run. model_user_args List parameters passed model run. Default = NULL. example : list(   list(   "prob_severe" = runif(17),   "tt_dur_get_ox_survive" = c(0, 10),   "gamma_get_ox_survive" = 0.2),   list(   "prob_severe" = runif(17),   "tt_dur_get_mv_survive" = c(0, 5),   "gamma_get_mv_survive" = 0.1)   ) list length number replicates simulations. list element list elements named match arguments expected odin model r. suitable set model parameters simulation 2 replicates. arguments list.

title:
Provide projections from calibrated simulations by changing RO, contact
matrices or bed availability. — projections
text: user can specify changes R0, contact matrices bed provision, come effect current day calibration. changes can either set specific values change relative values original simulation. change requested, simulation use parameters chosen calibration run. extends previous versions projections can now pass lists argument get passed simulation replicate.

what: Fit nimue to a given set of death data via the particle and optimisation exploration approach. — rt_optimise
title: Fit nimue to a given set of death data via the particle and optimisation exploration approach. — rt_optimise
text: given number samples given parameter uncertainty distribution function, approach iteratively fits Rt trend provided death data returns nimue_simulation object future usage scenario modelling.

title: Fit nimue to a given set of death data via the particle and optimisation exploration approach. — rt_optimise
code: rt_optimise(   data,   distribution,   squire_model,   parameters,   start_date,   parallel = FALSE,   rt_spacing = 14,   k = 2,   n_particles = 14,   initial_infections_interval = c(5, 500),   rt_interval = c(0.5, 20) )

title: Fit nimue to a given set of death data via the particle and optimisation exploration approach. — rt_optimise
text: data data frame deaths occuring given time frame. Given format: deaths(integer), date_start(date), date_end(date). Must least one death period set Rt trend changes (.e. 14 day period default) period can overlap changes. distribution list samples(list) names specifying parameters. squire_model model object desired type use, .e. squire, nimue. parameters list parameters keep across samples. start_date Date epidemic begins, parameters distribution formatted relative date, necessary. parallel Run sample concurrently, uses future::plan set user. Default = FALSE. rt_spacing Number days Rt trend, default = 14 days. k Control dispersion negative binomial likelihood, default = 2. n_particles many particles explore uniformly interval initial infections, default = 7. initial_infections_interval range initial number infections explore, default = c(5, 500). rt_interval range values Rt can take, default = c(0.5, 20).

title: Fit nimue to a given set of death data via the particle and optimisation exploration approach. — rt_optimise
text: object type rt_optimised, (model type).

title: Fit nimue to a given set of death data via the particle and optimisation exploration approach. — rt_optimise
text: NOTE: death curves periods 0's rt_interval's lower bound must greater 0 else likely fail overcome low infective population Rt tend unrealistically large number. function progressr enabled, progressr::handlers(global = TRUE) can used view progress samples.
